No, it was a lot of stress for very little gain

I would recommend this course if the student already has a limited background in economics, but I think it would probably be a more beneficial experience for a student with no prior knowledge of microeconomics to take the seminar given the fact that they have more opportunity to engage with the professor and ask questions to clarify material. Overall, I think the course was fairly good but suffered from problems related to the number of students enrolled.
Yes. I was not sure what major I wanted to pursue as an incoming freshman but I am now leaning towards economics after taking this course.
Yes, as I feel like economics is integral to a good education.

If the student was interested in Economics, I would recommend this course. I think it depends on what kind of learner you are and what you are interested in. This course is interesting, but takes lots of effort because learning information in lecture is very different than learning it in a small group.
Take this class but take it with friends. Its structure is too unorganized to work through alone.
Yes, if interested in econ or anything business related
I recommend this course to students who need to take it for their major, or for those who want an economics background. I learned a lot in the course!
If you are passionate about Econ take it. Otherwise no, you wont get anything out of it .
Yes, I would recommend it, as I believe it has an interesting approach for students who have no prior experience with economics.
if you want to be an econ major then you must take it, but I wouldn't recommend it due to the poor teaching style of it.
Yeah, the workload isnt bad and its great to see if you like Economics.
It is pretty much what you would expect out of an introductory level economics class. If you are thinking of taking economics, it is a decent into to see if you would even like the subject.
Yeah, it's intro.
yes, the knowledge gained is essential to every student
No. I do not think the large lecture is a good way to facilitate student learning. I would recommend other students to take the seminar instead of the lecture.
Yes, because it is a massive first-year course that is good for meeting people and all that.
Yes. I think its an important course for every student to at least be exposed to.
Yes, it is a good course to develop basic understanding of economics. However I would recommend other students do the smaller seminar versions of the course.
Only if they have to take it or if they want to explore econ more. It's not one of those courses you take just for the fun of it.

I think basic economic knowledge is useful for anyone to have, so for that reason I would recommend this course. I didn't take the seminar, however, so I can't comment on how it would compare. I would say that ECON 115 requires a LOT of self-drive and self-directed push to go to office hours, peer tutors, etc. when you don't understand, which can be tiring/difficult in its own way.
I would recommend this course because it gives you a good understanding of economics at the level you interact with it, but also opens your mind to the many other ways to interact with the material.
Yeah, it is an adequate course I'd say. Does what it says it does.
Only if they are interested in economics.

No, I'd suggest taking the 110 seminar instead. The engagement issue is too much to really be successful. You can definitely learn a lot, but that will be through maximizing your use of the resources available.

Listen here and listen carefully - this class is NO JOKE. If you're one of those kids that's just chilling thinking this course would be a nice opportunity to try out economics at Yale, be careful. I came in thinking this course would be a breeze but ended up investing most my time in doing well. The class is full of students with insane econ backgrounds, some who placed in Micro theory but chose to take intro micro instead. The teaching is not where it needs to be: you will genuinely not learn unless you read the textbooks. The TFs are far from helpful, so you're really on your own. The material is great, don't get me wrong. This semester's professor, Ms. Oster, was well-intentioned, but it was just not easy. Building economic intuition in this class is like being a fish out of water - you're scrambling the entire semester. Be sure this is what you want to do before you do it.
Yes I would. Because it is mandatory for the economics major.
Yes
Yes, I think microeconomics is important as a field and the workload for this class isn't prohibitively heavy.
Yes, I would recommend it if you want to gain foundational knowledge on economics.
Mainly. Most people survived it, but based on what I've heard, I would rather take the seminar.
Yes, I think it served as a good introduction to the ideas behind economics and can be an interesting class even if you are not planning on going into the major.
Probably, I think the principles are important and the teaching was generally good.
Yes - itll either encourage you to pursue Econ further or at the very least be a useful set of insights
You may be better off learning microeconomics on your own over summer break.
Yes. It is a class one must take before graduating, whether you like it or not.
Yes I would, because it serves as a foundation for many more economics classes.

I would recommend if you're looking for a decent QR without too much complex math. Also a great class to take as an upperclassmen, because the freshmen are in a constant state of panic and you're just cruising.
Yes, because getting a foundation in microeconomics I think is key in understanding a lot of the events that occur everyday that impact many lives.
If they want/have to take an economics class, yes. It is a good introduction to more difficult Econ courses.
I would recommend this course to someone who is unsure of their interest level in economics and would like an overview of microeconomics.
Yeah; I took it for a QR credit and it's not too bad, not too mathy and does make me learn a lot.
Its a building block course, so yes.
No; it is a large lecture, and the material is not engaging enough for that format to be conducive to learning.

I think econ isn't for me, so my perception is probably skewed. I found that in general, there was a lot to learn by oneself, so if you're the type of student who has trouble figuring out exactly what you're confused by, take the seminar instead. The teachers have time to answer your questions but not to help you figure out what they are.
Yes, but if you havent taken economics previously (like in high school), be ready for quite a bit of work to understand the material.!
Yes I would because it is an interesting way of thinking.
I wouldn't, unless you are going to be an econ major. Other than that I think it would be a waste of a credit and a lot of your time. It just isn't very interesting in my opinion.
Yes because it will give you a good intro to economics.

Yes, I would recommend the class. Econ has a bad rap, but a lot of concepts from the class are relevant to subjects other than finance, like climate protection, social policy, and nonprofit strategy. I think that students can benefit from having a basic understanding of things like taxes, cost-benefit analysis, etc., since it offers us a different perspective on how society works. The quality of the lectures really depended on the professor. My suggestion to anyone taking this class is to really try to do as much independent practice as you can. While going to office hours and review sessions will serve you well in getting the right answers, you should try problems on your own first. Most questions on the P-sets and exams are fair. Some pose more of an intellectual challenge/conceptual application of the material, and these questions are mainly for the curve (which is pretty competitive, since everyone is actually trying to do well). Absolutely no need to spend money on the textbook for this class.
I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who wasn't planning on majoring in economics because of the lack of attention given to students, making it a very unnecessarily difficult class
Yes! It's important for everyone to take at least one economics course at Yale.

This is a course that one must take in order to pursue a major in economics. I really wish the course would be more accommodating and more helpful in terms of acting as an introductory course. I had no prior background in this course and it was rather difficult for me to grasp all of the concepts presented.

I would highly recommend Micro 115. While it isn't a breeze, it teaches all the fundamentals of Microeconomics that are useful to all students, not just Econ majors. I used most of the things I learned in 115 for understanding concepts in multiple other classes. Overall, the course allowed me to get a better understanding of economics and how I can apply that to the real world. While the lecture isn't very entertaining or engaging, the material is worth the time investment and the things I have learned have proven to be useful outside of class.
Only if they're actually interested in economics or if they need it for a major, because it's too hard to just take if you're interested (my personal opinion).
Yeah I definitely would recommend this class because it helps me understand the basic concepts at play and better grasp what is going on in economics.
It's a foundational course. Take it if you want to know microeconomics, but if you want to really understand/are very interested in the topic, the seminar version might be more appropriate
Yes. It is a great introduction to the Economics major.
No! Take the seminar.
Yes, it is a good introductory lecture and is good to follow.
I would recommend it because it is such a basic class that most college students take, but I think the class needs serious restructuring.
Yes, fun not to high pressure and a good way to get exposed to basic economic thinking.
I would recommend this course to students who have economics experience in highschool
I would recommend it, because it gives a good basis for future exploration of Economics courses and teaches some valuable skills.

No. I would never recomend this course because the professir does not explain concepts very well and more could be learnt from watching youtube videos online. The assesments are not fair and it was overall a bad experience.
Yes, it is a great opportunity to see if economics is going to be a subject you will want to study further.
I would recommend it because it's a requirement for a lot of classes in several disciplines.
I would recommend this course to a student looking to gain a better understanding of econ.
If someone wishes to learn the basics of microeconomics, this is probably the only course to take. Otherwise, it's not a very interesting class.

I'd be very careful with who I recommend this class to. I did not love it, but as a probably English major, it wasn't a class I totally expected myself to love. It's definitely a good way to meet a lot of first-years and study together in the first term, but unless future economics classes are desired, I probably wouldn't recommend it. Much of what I learned was completely unrelated to economics, which I guess is a good thing long term but I probably could've gotten it much better out of other classes where I also learned.
Yes, it is a good introduction to the subject area and I feel like I learned a lot.

I would recommend this course, but mostly because I think that most everyone should learn basic economic principles, and the course effectively teaches those. However, it is not particularly interesting/ intellectually stimulating, in my opinion (either the lecture style or the content of the course)
If you are interested in economics or just want to better understand how we make choices, this course gives a good foundation.
